column1: #Text=India-China border-treaty hoped to improve ties , facilitate trade

#Text=and China have settled long-time border disputes , and with freed up cross-border traffic look to creating what would be the largest trading bloc in the world , between the two most populous nations on the planet .
#Text=During a recent visit by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao to the Indian capital of Delhi , a border was finally agreed on paper .
#Text=" India and China can together reshape the world order , " Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said Monday .
#Text=" China has a large manufacturing base .

#Text=India agreed also  not to allow Tibetans to engage in anti-China political activities on its soil " , according to a report in The Economic Times of India .

column1: #Text=A new cross-border trade route would be allowed through Nathula , in Sikkim , and significant road work was to facilitate higher traffic , at least on the Chinese side .

#Text=Eleven guiding principles and political parameters for resolving the disagreement , were put forth in the document , including a commitment to enhance bilateral trade from the present US$ 13.6 billion to US$ 30 billion by 2010 — trade which only a decade ago was worth just US$ 1 billion .

#Text=" This matter tells us that as long as the two sides bear sincerity , and patience , the border between China and India will become a bridge linking the friendship of the two sides , " Wen said of the document he signed with Singh .
#Text=" A growing and stable China is in the interest of India .

#Text= It shows a lot of give and take on both sides , " said National Security Adviser M.K. Narayanan , India 's special representative for the border talks .

column1: #Text=The treaty " respect[s the ] status quo , and is tantamount to accepting the Line of Actual Control as the border between the two countries , " said Swaran Singh , a China expert at the Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi .
